skill.name: multi-agent-orchestration
skill.description: Orchestrate tasks across multiple AI providers (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini, Cursor, OpenCode, Ollama). Use when delegating tasks to specialized providers, routing based on capabilities, or implementing fallback strategies.
skill.summary: Route and delegate AI tasks to the optimal provider based on task requirements, capabilities, and cost considerations.
skill.author: Consiliency

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill providing routing guidance for AI provider delegation. All 326 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES - they are markdown documentation examples showing CLI commands and environment variables, not executable code. No security risks identified.

low_findings.title: Documentation contains CLI command examples
low_findings.description: The cookbook and reference files contain markdown code blocks showing CLI commands for various AI providers (gemini, codex, ollama). These are documentation examples only, not executable code within the skill.

low_findings.title: Documentation references API key environment variables
low_findings.description: Documentation instructs users to set GEMINI_API_KEY and OPENAI_API_KEY for provider authentication. This is standard practice for API integration and poses no security risk as the skill itself does not access these variables.

content.user_title: Intelligently Route Tasks to the Best AI Provider
content.value_statement: Managing multiple AI providers is complex with different capabilities and costs. This skill provides a decision framework and routing logic to automatically delegate tasks to the optimal provider based on requirements like context length, multimodal needs, sandboxed execution, or privacy constraints.
actual_capabilities: Route tasks to optimal AI provider based on task characteristics like context length, multimodal needs, sandboxing, or privacy requirements
Provide decision trees for common routing scenarios with clear guidance on when to use each provider
Delegate tasks to Claude, OpenAI Codex, Gemini, Cursor, OpenCode, or local Ollama models
Implement fallback strategies when primary providers are unavailable or rate-limited
Reference provider comparison matrix covering context windows, multimodal support, execution environments, and cost
Include cookbook examples for each provider with authentication setup and delegation patterns
limitations: Documentation-only skill that provides routing guidance but does not execute provider delegation itself
Requires users to manually install provider CLI tools and configure API keys before use
Does not manage conversation history or context transfer between different AI providers
Model names and capabilities may change over time and should be verified using the model-discovery skill

use_cases.title: Large codebase analysis and refactoring
use_cases.description: Route multi-file refactoring or architecture analysis to Gemini when the codebase exceeds 100k tokens, or keep in Claude for complex reasoning tasks that need deep understanding of patterns.

use_cases.title: Privacy-sensitive data processing
use_cases.description: Delegate confidential document analysis or internal code review to local Ollama models to ensure data never leaves your infrastructure while still getting AI assistance.

use_cases.title: Untrusted code execution and testing
use_cases.description: Route experimental code or user-submitted scripts to OpenAI Codex for execution in an isolated sandbox environment that prevents security risks to your local system.

prompt_templates.title: Basic provider routing
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to analyze a 150,000 token codebase for refactoring opportunities. Which AI provider should I use and why?
prompt_templates.scenario: Use when you need guidance on selecting the optimal provider for a specific task based on its characteristics

prompt_templates.title: Resilient multi-provider fallback
prompt_templates.prompt: Delegate this task to Gemini for its large context window. If Gemini is unavailable or rate-limited, try Claude as fallback. Show me the commands for both options.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use when you need a robust delegation strategy with automatic fallback options for high-availability workflows

prompt_templates.title: Privacy-constrained delegation
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to process confidential company documents. Route this to a local provider only and explain the privacy benefits.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use when handling sensitive data that must not be sent to external cloud providers due to compliance or security requirements

prompt_templates.title: Advanced multi-criteria routing
prompt_templates.prompt: I have 20 code review tasks. Route them optimally considering: task complexity, required context length, current provider costs, and availability. Provide a delegation plan.
prompt_templates.scenario: Use for batch processing where you need to optimize across multiple criteria like cost, performance, and provider availability

output_examples.input: I need to analyze a 150,000 token codebase for refactoring opportunities. Which provider should I use?
output: Reason: The task requires processing 150k tokens, which exceeds Claude's typical context window but fits comfortably within Gemini's 2M token limit.
Authentication: Set GEMINI_API_KEY or use interactive OAuth login
Command: gemini --model gemini-3-pro "Analyze this codebase for refactoring opportunities"
Next Steps: Read cookbook/gemini-cli.md for complete setup and delegation instructions

output_examples.input: Route this safely: I need to test untrusted Python code submitted by users.
output: Reason: Untrusted code execution requires a sandboxed environment. Codex provides isolated execution with no network access or persistent storage.
Security: Code runs in ephemeral container, automatically destroyed after execution
Alternative: Use local Docker container with Ollama for full control over sandbox configuration

output_examples.input: I have confidential medical records to analyze. Which provider preserves privacy?
output: Reason: Confidential data should never leave your infrastructure. Ollama runs entirely locally with no network transmission.
Privacy Benefit: All processing happens on your machine. No data sent to external APIs.
Setup: Install Ollama and pull a model like llama3 or mistral
Command: ollama run llama3 "Analyze these medical records for patterns"
Note: Cloud providers (Claude, Gemini, Codex) cannot be used for this task due to privacy constraints

best_practices: Always verify provider availability and authentication status before delegating high-volume or time-sensitive tasks to avoid mid-task failures
Use the model-discovery skill to fetch current model names and capabilities instead of relying on hardcoded version numbers that become stale
Explicitly document user consent and data handling policies before routing sensitive information to external cloud providers for compliance and privacy protection
anti_patterns: Delegating tasks that depend on prior conversation history to external providers that lack access to Claude's context, resulting in loss of important information
Hardcoding specific model version numbers in scripts or configurations that quickly become outdated when providers release new versions
Bypassing the routing decision tree and arbitrarily selecting a provider without considering task requirements, potentially wasting costs or missing capabilities

faq.question: What is the default provider when the routing decision is unclear?
faq.answer: Claude is configured as the default fallback provider via the DEFAULT_PROVIDER variable. Claude excels at general reasoning, complex coding tasks, and maintaining conversation context.

faq.question: How do I configure API authentication for different providers?
faq.answer: Set environment variables for cloud providers: OPENAI_API_KEY for OpenAI Codex, GEMINI_API_KEY for Gemini. Local providers like Ollama do not require API keys and run entirely on your machine.

faq.question: Can this skill be used completely offline without internet access?
faq.answer: Yes, Ollama and OpenCode providers can run entirely offline on your local machine. Cloud providers (Claude, OpenAI Codex, Gemini, Cursor) require active internet connectivity for API access.

faq.question: How should I handle tasks that depend on previous conversation context?
faq.answer: Keep context-dependent tasks within Claude rather than delegating them. External providers do not have access to your current Claude conversation history, which would result in loss of important context.

faq.question: Which provider should I use for multimodal tasks like video or audio analysis?
faq.answer: Route multimodal tasks to Gemini, which has native support for video, audio, and image understanding. Other providers in this skill have limited or no multimodal capabilities.

faq.question: How can I estimate costs before delegating high-volume tasks?
faq.answer: Enable CHECK_COST_STATUS in the skill configuration. Refer to the provider matrix documentation for current pricing information and use the model-discovery skill to check rate limits and quotas before batch operations.
